授業目的:
化学であれ、生物であれ、あらゆる実験に必要なデータ処理の基礎を学ぶ
Students will learn data organization/processing which helps them regardless of their major.
到達目標: 受講生が、実験データの数値処理の原理を理解できること。
授業方法:
[For attendance exempted students] The sessions will be done on-demand using the pdf files uploaded on OneDrive. The link to the material
is given near final field of this page. The source files for the programming sessions will also be given by the session. The students
are required to check the luna to find the upload and the report information.

第1回:
01_Diffusion
The concept of probability, combination and
permutation is central to dealing with random and real world data. In the
session, it is shown how a simple combination calculation leads to a partial
differentiation equation and its solution. The justification is done by
comparing the theoretical results with the experimental ones.

The students are recommended to read the pdf material
before the class for one hour and complete the report
when given. the answer will be delivered in a month.

02_Statistical_Mechanics
The session is added to this class to
show the basic ideas behind the statistical physics, such as the origin of
exp(-E/k B T). You may be conformable using these without being conscious
about them. Still, it is helpful to understand the origin, especially when
you stumble on a problem.

第10回:
10_Sampling_Theorem
The Sampling theorem plays the central
role in the sequential digital data processing. Despite relatively simple
conclusion drawn from the theorem, the effect of the sampling rate on
signals are hard to understand. In the session, we use FFT to visually
understand how sampling rates affect the data in the frequency domain.

The students are recommended to read the pdf material
before the class for one hour and complete the report
when given. the answer will be delivered in a month.
第11回:
11_Approximation_Reconstruction In Fourier Analysis and FFT, the
trigonometric functions such as sin, cos and exp plays the central role.
They are called basis. In the session, we introduce basis sets other than the
trigonometric functions, so that you can generalize the concept of Fourier
decomposition.
